001package io.github.ai4ci.functions;
002
003/**
004 * A linear interpolator implementation that performs piecewise linear
005 * interpolation between given data points.
006 * <p>
007 * <b>Input Constraints:</b>
008 * <ul>
009 * <li>The x array must be strictly increasing (x[i] &lt; x[i+1] for all i)</li>
010 * <li>The x and y arrays must have the same length</li>
011 * <li>Both arrays must contain at least 2 elements</li>
012 * <li>Arrays must not contain NaN or infinite values</li>
013 * </ul>
014 * <p>
015 * For input values outside the range [x[0], x[n-1]], the interpolator returns
016 * the boundary values (y[0] for x &lt;= x[0], y[n-1] for x &gt;= x[n-1]).
017 *
018 * @see Interpolator
019 */
020public class LinearInterpolator implements Interpolator {
021
022        /**
023         * Factory method to create a linear interpolator with the given data points.
024         *
025         * @param x the x-coordinates of the data points (must be strictly
026         *          increasing)
027         * @param y the y-coordinates of the data points
028         * @return a new LinearInterpolator instance
029         * @throws IllegalArgumentException if arrays have different lengths, x is
030         *                                  not strictly increasing, or arrays have
031         *                                  less than 2 elements
032         */
033        public static LinearInterpolator createLinearInterpolator(
034                        double[] x, double[] y
035        ) {
036                return new LinearInterpolator(x, y);
037        }
038
039        private final double[] x;
040
041        private final double[] y;
042
043        /**
044         * Constructs a linear interpolator with the given data points.
045         *
046         * @param x the x-coordinates of the data points (must be strictly
047         *          increasing)
048         * @param y the y-coordinates of the data points
049         * @throws IllegalArgumentException if arrays have different lengths, x is
050         *                                  not strictly increasing, or arrays have
051         *                                  less than 2 elements
052         */
053        private LinearInterpolator(double[] x, double[] y) {
054                Interpolator.checkInputs(x, y);
055                this.x = x;
056                this.y = y;
057        }
058
059        /**
060         * Computes the derivative (slope) of the interpolated function at the given
061         * x-coordinate. Returns 0.0 for values outside the interpolation range.
062         *
063         * @param x the x-coordinate to compute the derivative at
064         * @return the derivative (slope) of the interpolated function
065         */
066        @Override
067        public double differential(double x) {
068                if ((x <= this.x[0]) || (x >= this.x[this.x.length - 1])) return 0.0;
069
070                int i = 0;
071                while (this.x[i] < x) {
072                        i++;
073                }
074
075                double x1 = this.x[i - 1];
076                double x2 = this.x[i];
077                double y1 = this.y[i - 1];
078                double y2 = this.y[i];
079
080                return (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1);
081        }
082
083        /**
084         * Interpolates the value at the given x-coordinate using linear
085         * interpolation.
086         *
087         * @param x the x-coordinate to interpolate at
088         * @return the interpolated y-value
089         */
090        @Override
091        public double interpolate(double x) {
092                if (x <= this.x[0]) return this.y[0];
093                if (x >= this.x[this.x.length - 1]) return this.y[this.y.length - 1];
094
095                int i = 0;
096                while (this.x[i] < x) {
097                        i++;
098                }
099
100                double x1 = this.x[i - 1];
101                double x2 = this.x[i];
102                double y1 = this.y[i - 1];
103                double y2 = this.y[i];
104
105                return y1 + (y2 - y1) * (x - x1) / (x2 - x1);
106        }
107
108}
